topic.title: How easy is it to DoS a zite?
topic.body: So, say I don't like a zite and I want to prevent anyone from accessing it. I create hundreds of fake peers that all advertise as hosting the zite but don't actually return valid data. Will visitors to the zite be able to open the zite?

F-Droid FTW!

Unless ZeroNet is built into the mainstream browsers, it won't be adopted. Optimists in this thread underestimate the grip of inertia and the allergy of average user to setting up anything beyond the complexity of clicking on a link. Perhaps, small self-sufficient plug-and-play "router-like" boxes based on RPi could simplify setup and operation, but normie users won't bother buying them.

9_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu.body:
This problem has a very large scope. To really solve it, you'd need to implement a distributed reputation system, analogous to a distributed page rank (page rank is a search engine algorithm for ranking web pages based on links between them). Every user's reputation will need to be determined solely by other users that observe him. One you have a sufficiently resilient reputation measure, you can start weighing posts/articles accordingly.

Just like it is still possible to game google rank, it will be possible to game any conceivable system, but it would be pretty hard to do so, and therefore not worth it for your average spammer.
